message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. N-acetylcysteine is a mucolytic agent that works by breaking down disulfide bonds in mucoprotein molecules, thereby reducing the viscosity of mucus and improving air flow in patients with COPD. The other options do not relate to the drug's mechanism of action.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. N-acetylcysteine is a mucolytic agent that breaks disulfide bonds in mucus, making it easier to clear from the airways. It does not inhibit peptidoglycan crosslinking, phosphodiesterase, or breakdown leukocyte DNA, so options (A), (B), and (D) are incorrect.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. N-acetylcysteine is a mucolytic drug used to break down disulfide bonds in mucus, making it less viscid and easier to clear. This will help the patient who has a productive cough with large amounts of sputum. Options A, B, and D are unrelated to the mechanism of action of N-acetylcysteine.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. N-acetylcysteine is an antioxidant and mucolytic agent that can break disulfide bonds, reducing the viscosity of mucus and improving its clearance in the airways. This can help with the patient's productive cough and dyspnea seen in COPD patients. Inhibition of peptidoglycan crosslinking is not related to this drug's mechanism of action, and inhibition of phosphodiesterase and breakdown of leukocyte DNA are not relevant to the treatment of COPD.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Nebulized N-acetylcysteine is a mucolytic agent that breaks disulfide bonds in mucus, making it easier to expectorate. It does not inhibit peptidoglycan crosslinking, phosphodiesterase, or breakdown of leukocyte DNA.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. N-acetylcysteine is a mucolytic agent that breaks down disulfide bonds in mucus, making it easier to cough up. It is commonly used to treat COPD and other respiratory diseases. Inhibition of peptidoglycan crosslinking is the mechanism of action of antibiotics such as penicillin. Inhibition of phosphodiesterase is the mechanism of action of drugs such as sildenafil. Breakdown of leukocyte DNA is not a mechanism of action for any known medication.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. N-acetylcysteine is a mucolytic agent that works by breaking disulfide bonds in mucus, making it less viscous and easier to expectorate. It does not inhibit peptidoglycan crosslinking or phosphodiesterase, nor does it breakdown of leukocyte DNA.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. N-acetylcysteine is a mucolytic drug that breaks disulfide bonds in mucoproteins, thus reducing the viscosity of mucus and making it easier to cough up. It does not inhibit peptidoglycan crosslinking, phosphodiesterase, or breakdown of leukocyte DNA.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. N-acetylcysteine works by breaking disulfide bonds in mucus, which reduces its viscosity and makes it easier to expectorate. This is particularly useful in patients with COPD who have difficulty clearing their airways due to thick sputum. The other options do not apply to the mechanism of action of N-acetylcysteine.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. N-acetylcysteine is a mucolytic agent that breaks down disulfide bonds in mucus, making it easier to cough up. It does not inhibit peptidoglycan crosslinking, phosphodiesterase, or breakdown of leukocyte DNA.
